[Seminar 4 Slides](https://clanfear.github.io/ioc_crm/_lectures/quantitative-data-relationships/slides_quantitative-data-relationships.html)

Readings:

* Bueno de Mesquita, E. and Fowler, A. (2021) *Thinking Clearly with Data: A Guide to Quantitative Reasoning and Analysis*, Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press.
   * Read pp. 53—93: (1) Chapter 4: Correlation Requires Variation, and (2) Chapter 5: Regression for Describing and Forecasting

* [Huntington-Klein, N. (2022) *The Effect: An Introduction to Research Design and Causality*, New York, NY: Chapman and Hall/CRC Press.](https://theeffectbook.net/index.html) 
   * Read pp. 19—85: (1) Chapter 3: Describing Variables, (2) Chapter 4: Describing Relationships, and (3) Chapter 5: Identification

* [Sullivan, C.J. and McGloin, J.M. (2014) ‘Looking back to move forward: some thoughts on measuring crime and delinquency over the past 50 years’, *Journal of Research in Crime and Delinquency*, 51(4): 445-466.](http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0022427813520446)

* Maguire, M. & McVie, S. 2017. ‘Crime Data and Criminal Statistics: A critical reflection.’ in A. Liebling, S. Maruna, & L. McAra (eds.) *The Oxford Handbook of Criminology*, 6th Ed., Oxford: Oxford University Press, pp. 163-189
   * Download from Moodle
